column1: Intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) of the newborn is bleeding into the fluid-filled areas (ventricles) inside the brain.

The most common symptoms seen in premature infants include: - Breathing pauses (apnea) - Changes in blood pressure and heart rate - Decreased muscle tone - Decreased reflexes - Excessive sleep - Lethargy - Weak suck - Seizures and other abnormal movements
Babies born between 30 to 34 weeks may also have ultrasound screening if they have symptoms of the problem.
The health care team will try to keep the infant stable and treat any symptoms the baby may be having.
For example, a blood transfusion may be given to improve blood pressure and blood count.
Less than half of babies with lower-grade bleeding have long term problems.
Up to a third of babies with severe bleeding may die.
Neurological symptoms or fever in a baby with a shunt in place may indicate a blockage or infection.
Pregnant women who are high risk of delivering early should be given medicines called corticosteroids.
Some women who are on medicines that affect bleeding risks should get vitamin K before delivery.
